parameters.name: Transform Order
parameters.label: Transform Order
parameters.description:
From Derivative
		
		
		
		
		Jump to navigation
		Jump to search
		
The Light Components are objects which cast light into a 3D scene. With the light parameters you can control the color, brightness, and atmosphere of geometry lit by the light. A scene can also be viewed through a light's perspective, similar to a Camera COMP. 
Tip: To avoid a light from consuming compute time when it's off, make the Dimmer parameter less than .001.
See Geometry Viewer to learn about how you can inspect from a light.
lightCOMP_Class

The Xform parameter page controls the object component's transform in world space.

  xord -  - This allows you to specify the order in which the changes to your  will take place. Changing the Transform Order will change where things go much the same way as going a block and turning east gets you to a different place than turning east and then going a block. In matrix math terms, if we use the 'multiply vector on the right' (column vector) convention, a transform order of Scale, Rotate, Translate would be written as T * R * S * Position.

  t -  - This allows you to specify the amount of movement along any of the three axes; the amount, in degrees, of rotation around any of the three axes; and a non-uniform scaling along the three axes. As an alternative to entering the values directly into these fields, you can modify the values by manipulating the  in the Viewport with the Select & Transform state.

The Pre-Xform parameter page applies a transform to the object component the same way connecting another Object as a parent of this node does. The transform is applied to the left of the Xform page's parameters. In terms of matrix math, if we use the 'multiply on the right' (column vector) convention, the equation would be preXForm * xform * Position.

  c -  - You can modify the color of a light here by adjusting the red, green, and blue parameters.  Alternatively, clicking on the color swatch will open a dialog with HSV and/or RGB sliders allowing interactive color picking with a preview of the selected color.

  dimmer - This parameter changes the intensity of the light without affecting its hue. Lights with Dimmer intensity below 0.001 are ignored. This optimization allows lights that are set to 0.0 to not be calculated in a Render TOP.


			
  lighttype -  - Specifies the type of light.

 point - Radiates light equally in all directions. cone - A directional spotlight that uses cone angle, delta, and falloff to control the size and intensity of the light. distant - All light radiates from one direction vector.  This can be used to simulate lights at a far-off distance, for example, the sun. The light's position is ignored, only its direction is used.
			
  coneangle - This specifies the angle within which the light remains at full intensity. Decreasing the cone angle to between ten and forty degrees focuses the beam to spotlight proportions.


			
  conedelta - This value, in degrees, represents the angle outside the cone angle through which the light intensity drops from its maximum to zero. Beyond this area, no more light is cast.		



			
  coneroll - This parameter (a value between one and ten) defines how gently or suddenly the amount of light decreases between full intensity and zero intensity within the Cone Delta area.


			
  attenuated - Turn on this checkbox to enable distance-based attenuation of the light.


			
  attenuationstart - The distance from the light source where the light attenuation begins.


			
  attenuationend - The distance from the light source where the light attenuation ends (i.e., no light radiates beyond this point).


			
  attenuationexp - Controls how the light fades off between the Attenuation Start and End points.

Enabling shadows will cause this node to render the scene in a depth-only pass to create a shadow map. This map will then be used by Render TOPs when rendering to create shadows for objects lit by this light. The shadow map that is created can be obtained using a Depth TOP, for cases where custom rendering is being done.

  shadowtype -  - Sets the type of shadows cast by the light.

 off - Shadow casting off. hard2d - Hard shadows. soft2d - Soft shadows. custom - Allows the use of a Custom Shadow Map.
			
  shadowcasters - The Geometry COMPs that will cast shadows from this light.


			
  lightsize -  - Controls the size of the source light when using Soft or Custom shadows.

lightsize1 -lightsize2 -
			
  maxshadowsoftness - Fine tuning for the shadow's software when using Soft or Custom shadows.


			
  filtersamples - Controls how many samples to look up into the shadow map for each pixel when doing soft shadows.


			
  searchsteps - Controls how many steps to take to search for occlusion when doing soft shadows.


			
  polygonoffsetfactor - Adds an offset to the Z value that depends on how sloped the surface is to the viewer when rendering the shadow map. Helps avoid z-fighting artifacts.


			
  polygonoffsetunits - Adds a constant offset to the Z value when rendering the shadow map. Helps avoid z-fighting artifacts.


			
  shadowresolution -  - The resolution of the shadow's texture map used for the calculation.

shadowresolution1 -shadowresolution2 -
			
  shadowmap - The path to a TOP used for the light's shadow map.  See also Rendering Shadows.





  projection -  - A pop-up menu lets you choose the projection type.

 perspective - Uses a perspective projection. ortho - Uses an orthographic projection. custommatrix - A projection matrix specified by a ,  or a tdu.Matrix().
			
  aspectcorrect - Keeps the aspect ratio of the view correct when using the light as a camera to look through.


			
  orthowidth - Only active if Orthographic is chosen from the Projection pop-up menu. This specifies the width of the orthographic projection.


			
  useconeforfov - If the light is set to Cone Light type, enabling this option sets the FOV using the Cone Angle and Cone Delta parameters on the Light parameter page.


			
  viewanglemethod -  - This menu determines which method is used to define the camera's angle of view.

 horzfov - Uses the FOV Angle parameter below to set the camera's angle of view horizontally. vertfov - Uses the FOV Angle parameter below to set the camera's angle of view vertically. focalaperture - Uses the Focal Length and Aperture parameters below to define the camera's angle of view.
			
  fov - The field of view (FOV) angle is the angular extend of the scene imaged by the camera.


			
  focal - The parameter sets the focal length of the lens, zooming in and out. Perspective is flattened or exaggerated depending on focal length. Some interesting distortion effects can be acheived with this parameter.


			
  aperture - This value relates to the area through which light can pass for the camera.


			
  near - This control allows you to designate the near clipping planes. Geometry closer to the lens than these distances will not be visible.


			
  far - This control allows you to designate the far clipping planes. Geometry further away from the lens than these distances will not be visible.


			
  projmatrixop - When Custom Projection Matrix is selected, this parameters should be filled in with either a  or a  with a custom 4x4 projection matrix. If a  is used the first sample of the first 16 channels of the  are used to create a 4x4 matrix. The channels can be thought as being read row-by-row or column-by-column. If a  is given a 4x4 table should be used. The matrix convention used is column major, which means vectors/points are multiplied on the right of the matrix.


			
  customproj - Takes a  containing a GLSL shader to specify custom projection functions. You must provide two functions in this shader. Both functions must be provided and return correct results for your rendering to work in all cases. As a starting point, here are the definitions for these functions that are used when custom ones are not provided.		
  









			
The other convenience variations of these functions such as vec3 TDCamToProj(vec3 p) will automatically call the correct one of either of the two above functions. You can use uniforms/samplers in this shader code by declaring them here and providing them in the GLSL page of the Render TOP.

The Display parameter page controls the component's material and rendering settings.

  material - Selects a MAT to apply to the geometry inside.



  render - Whether the 's geometry is visible in the Render TOP. This parameter works in conjunction (logical AND) with the 's Render Flag.



  drawpriority - Determines the order in which the Components are drawn. Smaller values get drawn after larger values. The value is compared with other Components in the same parent , or if the  is the top level one listed in the Render 's '' parameter, then against other top-level Components listed there. This value is most often used to help with Transparency.



  pickpriority - When using a Render Pick CHOP or a Render Pick DAT, there is an option to have a 'Search Area'. If multiple objects are found within the search area, the pick priority can be used to select one object over another. A higher value will get picked over a lower value. This does not affect draw order, or objects that are drawn over each other on the same pixel. Only one will be visible for a pick per pixel.



  wcolor -  - Use the R, G, and B fields to set the 's color when displayed in wireframe shading mode.

 wcolorr - wcolorg - wcolorb -

  lightmask - By default all lights used in the Render TOP will affect geometry renderer. This parameter can be used to specify a sub-set of lights to be used for this particular geometry. The lights must be listed in the Render TOP as well as this parameter to be used.





The  parameter page sets the component's python extensions.  Please see extensions for more information.

  ext - Sequence of info for creating extensions on this component



  ext0object - A number of class instances that can be attached to the component.


    
  ext0name - Optional name to search by, instead of the instance class name.



  ext0promote - Controls whether or not the extensions are visible directly at the component level, or must be accessed through the .ext member.  Example:  n.Somefunction vs n.ext.Somefunction




  reinitextensions - Recompile all extension objects. Normally extension objects are compiled only when they are referenced and their definitions have changed.





The Common parameter page sets the component's node viewer and clone relationships.

  parentshortcut - Specifies a name you can use anywhere inside the component as the path to that component. See Parent Shortcut.



  opshortcut - Specifies a name you can use anywhere at all as the path to that component. See Global OP Shortcut.



  iop - Sequence header for internal operators.



  iop0shortcut - Specifies a name you can use anywhere inside the component as a path to "Internal " below. See Internal Operators.



  iop0op - The path to the Internal OP inside this component. See Internal Operators.




  nodeview -  - Determines what is displayed in the node viewer, also known as the Node Viewer. Some options will not be available depending on the  type (Object Component, Panel Component, Misc.)

 default - Displays the default viewer for the component type, a 3D Viewer for Object COMPS and a  Viewer for Panel COMPs. opviewer - Displays the node viewer from any operator specified in the Operator Viewer parameter below.

  opviewer - Select which operator's node viewer to use when the Node View parameter above is set to Operator .



  enablecloning - Control if the OP should be actively cloneing. Turning this off causes this node to stop cloning it's ' Master'.



  enablecloningpulse - Instantaneously clone the contents.



  clone -  to a component used as the Master Clone.



  loadondemand - Loads the component into memory only when required. Good to use for components that are not always used in the project.



  enableexternaltox - When on (default), the external  file will be loaded when the  starts and the contents of the  will match that of the external . This can be turned off to avoid loading from the referenced external  on startup if desired (the contents of the  are instead loaded from the  file). Useful if you wish to have a  reference an external  but not always load from it unless you specifically push the Re-Init Network parameter button.



  enableexternaltoxpulse - This button will re-load from the external  file (if present).



  externaltox -  to a  file on disk which will source the component's contents upon start of a . This allows for components to contain networks that can be updated independently. If the  file can not be found, whatever the  file was saved with will be loaded.



  reloadcustom - When this checkbox is enabled, the values of the component's Custom Parameters are reloaded when the .tox is reloaded. This only affects top-level parameters on the component, all parameters on nodes inside the component are always reloaded with the .tox.



  reloadbuiltin - When this checkbox is enabled, the values of the component's built-in parameters are reloaded when the .tox is reloaded. This only affects top-level parameters on the component, all parameters on nodes inside the component are always reloaded with the .tox.



  savebackup - When this checkbox is enabled, a backup copy of the component specified by the External  parameter is saved in the  file.  This backup copy will be used if the External  can not be found. This may happen if the  was renamed, deleted, or the  file is running on another computer that is missing component media.



  subcompname - When loading from an External  file, this option allows you to reach into the  and pull out a  and make that the top-level , ignoring everything else in the file (except for the contents of that ). For example if a  file named project1 contains project1/geo1, putting geo1 as the Sub- to Load, will result in geo1 being loaded in place of the current . If this parameter is blank, it just loads the  file normally using the top level  in the file.



  relpath -  - Set whether the child file paths within this  are relative to the  itself or the , or inherit from parent.

 inherit - Inherit setting from parent. project - The path, when specified as a relative path, will be relative to the  file. externaltox - The path, when specified as a relative path, will be relative to the  file. When no external  file is specified, or when Enable External  is not toggled on, this doesn't have any impact.

An Operator Family that contains its own Network. There are sixteen 3D Object Component and ten 2D Panel Component types. See also Network Path.



Hierarchy relates components with other components. There are two groups of Hierarchy in TouchDesigner.  3D Object Components, and 2D Panel Components. Hierarchies let one component to be positioned relative to another. Each group can be connected via lines between the bottoms/tops of nodes in a network, or by placing one component inside the other.



The sub-Family of Component types that are used to define and render 3D scenes. A Geometry Component is an Object that contains the 3D shapes to render. A Camera COMP and Light COMP are other Object types. Separately, "Objects" also refers to Python objects.



The location of an operator within the TouchDesigner environment, for example, /geo1/circle1, a node called circle1 in a component called geo1. The path / is called Root. This path is displayed at the top of every Pane, showing which Component's network you are currently in. To refer instead to a filesystem folder, directory, disk file or http: address, see Folder.



A Operator Family that reads, creates and modifies 3D points, polygons, lines, particles, surfaces, spheres and meatballs. Particles and point clouds are now done primarily on the GPU using TOPs.



An Operator Family which operate on Channels (a sequence of numbers (Samples)) which are used for animation, audio, mathematics, simulation, logic, UI construction, and data streamed from/to devices and protocols.



An Operator Family that manipulates text strings: multi-line text or tables. Multi-line text is often a python Script or GLSL Shader, but can be any multi-line text. Tables are rows and columns of cells, each containing a text string.



Each SOP has a list of Points. Each point has an XYZ 3D position value plus other optional attributes. Each polygon Primitive is defined by a vertex list, which is list of point numbers.



Operators that need 1 or more inputs are called Filters in TouchDesigner, like a Math CHOP. See Generator.



A polygon is a type of Primitive that is formed from a set of Vertices in 3D that are implicitly connected together to form a multi-edge shape.



The width and height of an image in pixels. Most TOPs, like the Movie File In TOP can set the image resolution. See Aspect Ratio for the width/height ratio of an image, taking into account non-square pixels.



MATs or Materials are an Operator Family that applies a Shader to a SOP or 3D Geometry Object for rendering textured surfaces with lighting.



An Operator Family that creates, composites and modifies images, and reads/writes images and movies to/from files and the network. TOPs run on the graphics card's GPU.



The 3D data held in SOPs and passed for rendering by the Geometry COMP.



Any component can be extended with its own Python classes which contain python functions and data.



A Parent Shortcut is a parameter on a component that contains a name that you can use anywhere inside the component to refer to that component using the syntax parent.Name, for example parent.Effect.width to obtain panel width.



A name for a component that is accessible from any node in a project, which can be declared in a component's Global Operator Shortcut parameter.



Any of the procedural data operators. OPs do all the work in TouchDesigner. They "cook" and output data to other OPs, which ultimately result in new images, data and audio being generated. See Node.



Operator shortcuts are Python objects that return operators (or sometimes parameters). These include Parent Shortcuts for accessing a component from within that component, and Global OP Shortcuts that access a unique component from anywhere in TouchDesigner.



The viewer of a node can be (1) the interior of a node (the Node Viewer), (2) a floating window (RMB->View... on node), or (3) a Pane that graphically shows the results of an operator.



A custom interactive control panel built within TouchDesigner. Panels are created using Panel Components.



Cloning makes multiple components match the contents of a master component. A Component whose Clone parameter is set will be forced to contain the same nodes, wiring and parameters as its master component. Cloning does not create new components as does the Replicator COMP.



To "pulse" a parameter is to send it a signal from (1) an exported CHOP channel or (2) a python command or (3) a mouse click that causes a new action to occur immediately. A pulse via python is via the .pulse() function on a pulse-type parameter, such as Reset parameter in a Speed CHOP. A pulse from a CHOP is typically a 0 to 1 to 0 signal in an exported channel.



TouchDesigner Component file, the file type used to save a Component of your TouchDesigner project.



TOuch Environment file, the file type used by TouchDesigner to save your entire project.



An Operator Family that contains its own Network. There are sixteen 3D Object Component and ten 2D Panel Component types. See also Network Path.



There are 2 kinds of parenting. The "parent component" is the component in which a node resides. The metaphor is extended to include grand parents, grand-grand parents, etc. The root / is the ultimate parent to all nodes. See also 3D Parenting and panel Parenting.

  dimmer - This parameter changes the intensity of the light without affecting its hue. Lights with Dimmer intensity below 0.001 are ignored. This optimization allows lights that are set to 0.0 to not be calculated in a Render TOP.

This can be used to simulate lights at a far-off distance, for example, the sun. The light's position is ignored, only its direction is used.

Enabling shadows will cause this node to render the scene in a depth-only pass to create a shadow map. This map will then be used by Render TOPs when rendering to create shadows for objects lit by this light. The shadow map that is created can be obtained using a Depth TOP, for cases where custom rendering is being done.

An Operator Family that contains its own Network. There are sixteen 3D Object Component and ten 2D Panel Component types. See also Network Path.



Hierarchy relates components with other components. There are two groups of Hierarchy in TouchDesigner.  3D Object Components, and 2D Panel Components. Hierarchies let one component to be positioned relative to another. Each group can be connected via lines between the bottoms/tops of nodes in a network, or by placing one component inside the other.



The sub-Family of Component types that are used to define and render 3D scenes. A Geometry Component is an Object that contains the 3D shapes to render. A Camera COMP and Light COMP are other Object types. Separately, "Objects" also refers to Python objects.



The location of an operator within the TouchDesigner environment, for example, /geo1/circle1, a node called circle1 in a component called geo1. The path / is called Root. This path is displayed at the top of every Pane, showing which Component's network you are currently in. To refer instead to a filesystem folder, directory, disk file or http: address, see Folder.



A Operator Family that reads, creates and modifies 3D points, polygons, lines, particles, surfaces, spheres and meatballs. Particles and point clouds are now done primarily on the GPU using TOPs.



An Operator Family which operate on Channels (a sequence of numbers (Samples)) which are used for animation, audio, mathematics, simulation, logic, UI construction, and data streamed from/to devices and protocols.



An Operator Family that manipulates text strings: multi-line text or tables. Multi-line text is often a python Script or GLSL Shader, but can be any multi-line text. Tables are rows and columns of cells, each containing a text string.



Each SOP has a list of Points. Each point has an XYZ 3D position value plus other optional attributes. Each polygon Primitive is defined by a vertex list, which is list of point numbers.



Operators that need 1 or more inputs are called Filters in TouchDesigner, like a Math CHOP. See Generator.



A polygon is a type of Primitive that is formed from a set of Vertices in 3D that are implicitly connected together to form a multi-edge shape.



The width and height of an image in pixels. Most TOPs, like the Movie File In TOP can set the image resolution. See Aspect Ratio for the width/height ratio of an image, taking into account non-square pixels.



MATs or Materials are an Operator Family that applies a Shader to a SOP or 3D Geometry Object for rendering textured surfaces with lighting.



An Operator Family that creates, composites and modifies images, and reads/writes images and movies to/from files and the network. TOPs run on the graphics card's GPU.



The 3D data held in SOPs and passed for rendering by the Geometry COMP.



Any component can be extended with its own Python classes which contain python functions and data.



A Parent Shortcut is a parameter on a component that contains a name that you can use anywhere inside the component to refer to that component using the syntax parent.Name, for example parent.Effect.width to obtain panel width.



A name for a component that is accessible from any node in a project, which can be declared in a component's Global Operator Shortcut parameter.



Any of the procedural data operators. OPs do all the work in TouchDesigner. They "cook" and output data to other OPs, which ultimately result in new images, data and audio being generated. See Node.



Operator shortcuts are Python objects that return operators (or sometimes parameters). These include Parent Shortcuts for accessing a component from within that component, and Global OP Shortcuts that access a unique component from anywhere in TouchDesigner.



The viewer of a node can be (1) the interior of a node (the Node Viewer), (2) a floating window (RMB->View... on node), or (3) a Pane that graphically shows the results of an operator.



A custom interactive control panel built within TouchDesigner. Panels are created using Panel Components.



Cloning makes multiple components match the contents of a master component. A Component whose Clone parameter is set will be forced to contain the same nodes, wiring and parameters as its master component. Cloning does not create new components as does the Replicator COMP.



To "pulse" a parameter is to send it a signal from (1) an exported CHOP channel or (2) a python command or (3) a mouse click that causes a new action to occur immediately. A pulse via python is via the .pulse() function on a pulse-type parameter, such as Reset parameter in a Speed CHOP. A pulse from a CHOP is typically a 0 to 1 to 0 signal in an exported channel.



TouchDesigner Component file, the file type used to save a Component of your TouchDesigner project.



TOuch Environment file, the file type used by TouchDesigner to save your entire project.



An Operator Family that contains its own Network. There are sixteen 3D Object Component and ten 2D Panel Component types. See also Network Path.



There are 2 kinds of parenting. The "parent component" is the component in which a node resides. The metaphor is extended to include grand parents, grand-grand parents, etc. The root / is the ultimate parent to all nodes. See also 3D Parenting and panel Parenting.

parameters.name: Transform Order
parameters.label: Transform Order
parameters.description:
The Light Components are objects which cast light into a 3D scene. With the light parameters you can control the color, brightness, and atmosphere of geometry lit by the light. A scene can also be viewed through a light's perspective, similar to a Camera COMP. 
Tip: To avoid a light from consuming compute time when it's off, make the Dimmer parameter less than .001.
See Geometry Viewer to learn about how you can inspect from a light.
lightCOMP_Class

Changing the Transform Order will change where things go much the same way as going a block and turning east gets you to a different place than turning east and then going a block. In matrix math terms, if we use the 'multiply vector on the right' (column vector) convention, a transform order of Scale, Rotate, Translate would be written as T * R * S * Position.

  dimmer - This parameter changes the intensity of the light without affecting its hue. Lights with Dimmer intensity below 0.001 are ignored. This optimization allows lights that are set to 0.0 to not be calculated in a Render TOP.


			
  lighttype -  - Specifies the type of light.

 point - Radiates light equally in all directions. cone - A directional spotlight that uses cone angle, delta, and falloff to control the size and intensity of the light. distant - All light radiates from one direction vector.  This can be used to simulate lights at a far-off distance, for example, the sun. The light's position is ignored, only its direction is used.
			
  coneangle - This specifies the angle within which the light remains at full intensity. Decreasing the cone angle to between ten and forty degrees focuses the beam to spotlight proportions.


			
  conedelta - This value, in degrees, represents the angle outside the cone angle through which the light intensity drops from its maximum to zero. Beyond this area, no more light is cast.		



			
  coneroll - This parameter (a value between one and ten) defines how gently or suddenly the amount of light decreases between full intensity and zero intensity within the Cone Delta area.


			
  attenuated - Turn on this checkbox to enable distance-based attenuation of the light.


			
  attenuationstart - The distance from the light source where the light attenuation begins.


			
  attenuationend - The distance from the light source where the light attenuation ends (i.e., no light radiates beyond this point).


			
  attenuationexp - Controls how the light fades off between the Attenuation Start and End points.

Enabling shadows will cause this node to render the scene in a depth-only pass to create a shadow map. This map will then be used by Render TOPs when rendering to create shadows for objects lit by this light. The shadow map that is created can be obtained using a Depth TOP, for cases where custom rendering is being done.

  shadowtype -  - Sets the type of shadows cast by the light.

 off - Shadow casting off. hard2d - Hard shadows. soft2d - Soft shadows. custom - Allows the use of a Custom Shadow Map.
			
  shadowcasters - The Geometry COMPs that will cast shadows from this light.

lightsize1 -lightsize2 -

  filtersamples - Controls how many samples to look up into the shadow map for each pixel when doing soft shadows.


			
  searchsteps - Controls how many steps to take to search for occlusion when doing soft shadows.


			
  polygonoffsetfactor - Adds an offset to the Z value that depends on how sloped the surface is to the viewer when rendering the shadow map. Helps avoid z-fighting artifacts.


			
  polygonoffsetunits - Adds a constant offset to the Z value when rendering the shadow map. Helps avoid z-fighting artifacts.


			
  shadowresolution -  - The resolution of the shadow's texture map used for the calculation.

shadowresolution1 -shadowresolution2 -

  aspectcorrect - Keeps the aspect ratio of the view correct when using the light as a camera to look through.

  fov - The field of view (FOV) angle is the angular extend of the scene imaged by the camera.


			
  focal - The parameter sets the focal length of the lens, zooming in and out. Perspective is flattened or exaggerated depending on focal length. Some interesting distortion effects can be acheived with this parameter.

If a  is used the first sample of the first 16 channels of the  are used to create a 4x4 matrix. The channels can be thought as being read row-by-row or column-by-column. If a  is given a 4x4 table should be used. The matrix convention used is column major, which means vectors/points are multiplied on the right of the matrix.

Both functions must be provided and return correct results for your rendering to work in all cases. The other convenience variations of these functions such as vec3 TDCamToProj(vec3 p) will automatically call the correct one of either of the two above functions. You can use uniforms/samplers in this shader code by declaring them here and providing them in the GLSL page of the Render TOP.

The value is compared with other Components in the same parent , or if the  is the top level one listed in the Render 's '' parameter, then against other top-level Components listed there. This value is most often used to help with Transparency.

If multiple objects are found within the search area, the pick priority can be used to select one object over another. A higher value will get picked over a lower value. This does not affect draw order, or objects that are drawn over each other on the same pixel. Only one will be visible for a pick per pixel.

An Operator Family that contains its own Network. There are sixteen 3D Object Component and ten 2D Panel Component types. See also Network Path.



Hierarchy relates components with other components. There are two groups of Hierarchy in TouchDesigner.  3D Object Components, and 2D Panel Components. Hierarchies let one component to be positioned relative to another. Each group can be connected via lines between the bottoms/tops of nodes in a network, or by placing one component inside the other.



The sub-Family of Component types that are used to define and render 3D scenes. A Geometry Component is an Object that contains the 3D shapes to render. A Camera COMP and Light COMP are other Object types. Separately, "Objects" also refers to Python objects.



The location of an operator within the TouchDesigner environment, for example, /geo1/circle1, a node called circle1 in a component called geo1. The path / is called Root. This path is displayed at the top of every Pane, showing which Component's network you are currently in. To refer instead to a filesystem folder, directory, disk file or http: address, see Folder.



A Operator Family that reads, creates and modifies 3D points, polygons, lines, particles, surfaces, spheres and meatballs. Particles and point clouds are now done primarily on the GPU using TOPs.



An Operator Family which operate on Channels (a sequence of numbers (Samples)) which are used for animation, audio, mathematics, simulation, logic, UI construction, and data streamed from/to devices and protocols.



An Operator Family that manipulates text strings: multi-line text or tables. Multi-line text is often a python Script or GLSL Shader, but can be any multi-line text. Tables are rows and columns of cells, each containing a text string.



Each SOP has a list of Points. Each point has an XYZ 3D position value plus other optional attributes. Each polygon Primitive is defined by a vertex list, which is list of point numbers.



Operators that need 1 or more inputs are called Filters in TouchDesigner, like a Math CHOP. See Generator.



A polygon is a type of Primitive that is formed from a set of Vertices in 3D that are implicitly connected together to form a multi-edge shape.



The width and height of an image in pixels. Most TOPs, like the Movie File In TOP can set the image resolution. See Aspect Ratio for the width/height ratio of an image, taking into account non-square pixels.



MATs or Materials are an Operator Family that applies a Shader to a SOP or 3D Geometry Object for rendering textured surfaces with lighting.



An Operator Family that creates, composites and modifies images, and reads/writes images and movies to/from files and the network. TOPs run on the graphics card's GPU.



The 3D data held in SOPs and passed for rendering by the Geometry COMP.



Any component can be extended with its own Python classes which contain python functions and data.



A Parent Shortcut is a parameter on a component that contains a name that you can use anywhere inside the component to refer to that component using the syntax parent.Name, for example parent.Effect.width to obtain panel width.



A name for a component that is accessible from any node in a project, which can be declared in a component's Global Operator Shortcut parameter.



Any of the procedural data operators. OPs do all the work in TouchDesigner. They "cook" and output data to other OPs, which ultimately result in new images, data and audio being generated. See Node.



Operator shortcuts are Python objects that return operators (or sometimes parameters). These include Parent Shortcuts for accessing a component from within that component, and Global OP Shortcuts that access a unique component from anywhere in TouchDesigner.



The viewer of a node can be (1) the interior of a node (the Node Viewer), (2) a floating window (RMB->View... on node), or (3) a Pane that graphically shows the results of an operator.



A custom interactive control panel built within TouchDesigner. Panels are created using Panel Components.



Cloning makes multiple components match the contents of a master component. A Component whose Clone parameter is set will be forced to contain the same nodes, wiring and parameters as its master component. Cloning does not create new components as does the Replicator COMP.



To "pulse" a parameter is to send it a signal from (1) an exported CHOP channel or (2) a python command or (3) a mouse click that causes a new action to occur immediately. A pulse via python is via the .pulse() function on a pulse-type parameter, such as Reset parameter in a Speed CHOP. A pulse from a CHOP is typically a 0 to 1 to 0 signal in an exported channel.



TouchDesigner Component file, the file type used to save a Component of your TouchDesigner project.



TOuch Environment file, the file type used by TouchDesigner to save your entire project.



An Operator Family that contains its own Network. There are sixteen 3D Object Component and ten 2D Panel Component types. See also Network Path.



There are 2 kinds of parenting. The "parent component" is the component in which a node resides. The metaphor is extended to include grand parents, grand-grand parents, etc. The root / is the ultimate parent to all nodes. See also 3D Parenting and panel Parenting.

xord -  - This allows you to specify the order in which the changes to your  will take place. Changing the Transform Order will change where things go much the same way as going a block and turning east gets you to a different place than turning east and then going a block. In matrix math terms, if we use the 'multiply vector on the right' (column vector) convention, a transform order of Scale, Rotate, Translate would be written as T * R * S * Position.

parameters.name: Light Color
parameters.label: Light Color
parameters.description:
c -  - You can modify the color of a light here by adjusting the red, green, and blue parameters.  Alternatively, clicking on the color swatch will open a dialog with HSV and/or RGB sliders allowing interactive color picking with a preview of the selected color.

 cr - cg - cb -

parameters.name: Red
parameters.label: Red
parameters.description: cr - cg - cb -

parameters.name: Dimmer
parameters.label: Dimmer
parameters.description: dimmer - This parameter changes the intensity of the light without affecting its hue. Lights with Dimmer intensity below 0.001 are ignored. This optimization allows lights that are set to 0.0 to not be calculated in a Render TOP.

parameters.name: Light Type
parameters.label: Light Type
parameters.description:
lighttype -  - Specifies the type of light.

 point - Radiates light equally in all directions. cone - A directional spotlight that uses cone angle, delta, and falloff to control the size and intensity of the light. distant - All light radiates from one direction vector.  This can be used to simulate lights at a far-off distance, for example, the sun. The light's position is ignored, only its direction is used.

parameters.name: Point Light
parameters.label: Point Light
parameters.description: point - Radiates light equally in all directions. cone - A directional spotlight that uses cone angle, delta, and falloff to control the size and intensity of the light. distant - All light radiates from one direction vector.  This can be used to simulate lights at a far-off distance, for example, the sun. The light's position is ignored, only its direction is used.

parameters.name: Cone Angle
parameters.label: Cone Angle
parameters.description: coneangle - This specifies the angle within which the light remains at full intensity. Decreasing the cone angle to between ten and forty degrees focuses the beam to spotlight proportions.

parameters.name: Cone Delta
parameters.label: Cone Delta
parameters.description: conedelta - This value, in degrees, represents the angle outside the cone angle through which the light intensity drops from its maximum to zero. Beyond this area, no more light is cast.

parameters.name: Cone Rolloff
parameters.label: Cone Rolloff
parameters.description: coneroll - This parameter (a value between one and ten) defines how gently or suddenly the amount of light decreases between full intensity and zero intensity within the Cone Delta area.

parameters.name: Distance-Attenuated
parameters.label: Distance-Attenuated
parameters.description: attenuated - Turn on this checkbox to enable distance-based attenuation of the light.

parameters.name: Attenuation Start
parameters.label: Attenuation Start
parameters.description: attenuationstart - The distance from the light source where the light attenuation begins.

parameters.name: Attenuation End
parameters.label: Attenuation End
parameters.description: attenuationend - The distance from the light source where the light attenuation ends (i.e., no light radiates beyond this point).

parameters.name: Attenuation Rolloff
parameters.label: Attenuation Rolloff
parameters.description: attenuationexp - Controls how the light fades off between the Attenuation Start and End points.

parameters.label: Projector Map Type

projmaptype -  -

parameters.name: Projector Map Mode
parameters.label: Projector Map Mode
parameters.description:
projmapmode -  - Specify how the projection map is applied

 simplehorzfov - Uses field of view based on the Projector Angle parameter below. useview - Uses the settings on the View page of parameters.

parameters.name: Simple Horizontal FOV
parameters.label: Simple Horizontal FOV
parameters.description: simplehorzfov - Uses field of view based on the Projector Angle parameter below. useview - Uses the settings on the View page of parameters.

parameters.name: Projector Angle
parameters.label: Projector Angle
parameters.description: projangle - Specifies the cone angle spread of the projector map, similar to how the Cone Angle parameter works for Cone Lights.

parameters.name: Polygon Front Faces
parameters.label: Polygon Front Faces
parameters.description:
frontfacelit -  - Controls how the polygon's normal is used to light the front face of the polygon. For more information refer to the Two-Sided Lighting article.

 frontlit - backlit -

parameters.name: Front Lit
parameters.label: Front Lit
parameters.description: frontlit - backlit -

parameters.name: Polygon Back Faces
parameters.label: Polygon Back Faces
parameters.description:
backfacelit -  - Controls how the polygon's normal is used to light the back face of the polygon. For more information refer to the Two-Sided Lighting article.

 frontlit - backlit -

parameters.name: Front Lit
parameters.label: Front Lit
parameters.description: frontlit - backlit -

parameters.name: Shadow Type
parameters.label: Shadow Type
parameters.description:
shadowtype -  - Sets the type of shadows cast by the light.

 off - Shadow casting off. hard2d - Hard shadows. soft2d - Soft shadows. custom - Allows the use of a Custom Shadow Map.

parameters.name: Off
parameters.label: Off
parameters.description: off - Shadow casting off. hard2d - Hard shadows. soft2d - Soft shadows. custom - Allows the use of a Custom Shadow Map.

parameters.name: Shadow Casters
parameters.label: Shadow Casters
parameters.description: shadowcasters - The Geometry COMPs that will cast shadows from this light.

parameters.name: Light Size
parameters.label: Light Size
parameters.description:
lightsize -  - Controls the size of the source light when using Soft or Custom shadows.

lightsize1 -lightsize2 -

parameters.name: Max Shadow Softness
parameters.label: Max Shadow Softness
parameters.description: maxshadowsoftness - Fine tuning for the shadow's software when using Soft or Custom shadows.

parameters.name: Filter Samples
parameters.label: Filter Samples
parameters.description: filtersamples - Controls how many samples to look up into the shadow map for each pixel when doing soft shadows.

parameters.name: Search Steps
parameters.label: Search Steps
parameters.description: searchsteps - Controls how many steps to take to search for occlusion when doing soft shadows.

parameters.name: Polygon Offset Factor
parameters.label: Polygon Offset Factor
parameters.description: polygonoffsetfactor - Adds an offset to the Z value that depends on how sloped the surface is to the viewer when rendering the shadow map. Helps avoid z-fighting artifacts.

parameters.name: Polygon Offset Units
parameters.label: Polygon Offset Units
parameters.description: polygonoffsetunits - Adds a constant offset to the Z value when rendering the shadow map. Helps avoid z-fighting artifacts.

parameters.name: Shadow Resolution
parameters.label: Shadow Resolution
parameters.description:
shadowresolution -  - The resolution of the shadow's texture map used for the calculation.

shadowresolution1 -shadowresolution2 -

parameters.name: Custom Shadow Map
parameters.label: Custom Shadow Map
parameters.description: shadowmap - The path to a TOP used for the light's shadow map.  See also Rendering Shadows.

parameters.name: Projection
parameters.label: Projection
parameters.description:
projection -  - A pop-up menu lets you choose the projection type.

 perspective - Uses a perspective projection. ortho - Uses an orthographic projection. custommatrix - A projection matrix specified by a ,  or a tdu.Matrix().

parameters.name: Perspective
parameters.label: Perspective
parameters.description: perspective - Uses a perspective projection. ortho - Uses an orthographic projection. custommatrix - A projection matrix specified by a ,  or a tdu.Matrix().

parameters.name: Aspect Correct Projection
parameters.label: Aspect Correct Projection
parameters.description: aspectcorrect - Keeps the aspect ratio of the view correct when using the light as a camera to look through.

parameters.name: Ortho Width
parameters.label: Ortho Width
parameters.description: orthowidth - Only active if Orthographic is chosen from the Projection pop-up menu. This specifies the width of the orthographic projection.

parameters.name: Use Cone Angle/Delta for FOV
parameters.label: Use Cone Angle/Delta for FOV
parameters.description: useconeforfov - If the light is set to Cone Light type, enabling this option sets the FOV using the Cone Angle and Cone Delta parameters on the Light parameter page.

parameters.name: Viewing Angle Method
parameters.label: Viewing Angle Method
parameters.description:
viewanglemethod -  - This menu determines which method is used to define the camera's angle of view.

 horzfov - Uses the FOV Angle parameter below to set the camera's angle of view horizontally. vertfov - Uses the FOV Angle parameter below to set the camera's angle of view vertically. focalaperture - Uses the Focal Length and Aperture parameters below to define the camera's angle of view.

parameters.name: Horizontal FOV
parameters.label: Horizontal FOV
parameters.description: horzfov - Uses the FOV Angle parameter below to set the camera's angle of view horizontally. vertfov - Uses the FOV Angle parameter below to set the camera's angle of view vertically. focalaperture - Uses the Focal Length and Aperture parameters below to define the camera's angle of view.

parameters.name: FOV Angle
parameters.label: FOV Angle
parameters.description: fov - The field of view (FOV) angle is the angular extend of the scene imaged by the camera.

parameters.name: Focal Length
parameters.label: Focal Length
parameters.description: focal - The parameter sets the focal length of the lens, zooming in and out. Perspective is flattened or exaggerated depending on focal length. Some interesting distortion effects can be acheived with this parameter.

parameters.name: Aperture
parameters.label: Aperture
parameters.description: aperture - This value relates to the area through which light can pass for the camera.

parameters.name: Near
parameters.label: Near
parameters.description: near - This control allows you to designate the near clipping planes. Geometry closer to the lens than these distances will not be visible.

parameters.name: Far
parameters.label: Far
parameters.description: far - This control allows you to designate the far clipping planes. Geometry further away from the lens than these distances will not be visible.

parameters.name: Proj Matrix/CHOP/DAT
parameters.label: Proj Matrix/CHOP/DAT
parameters.description: projmatrixop - When Custom Projection Matrix is selected, this parameters should be filled in with either a  or a  with a custom 4x4 projection matrix. If a  is used the first sample of the first 16 channels of the  are used to create a 4x4 matrix. The channels can be thought as being read row-by-row or column-by-column. If a  is given a 4x4 table should be used. The matrix convention used is column major, which means vectors/points are multiplied on the right of the matrix.

parameters.name: Custom Projection GLSL DAT
parameters.label: Custom Projection GLSL DAT
parameters.description:
customproj - Takes a  containing a GLSL shader to specify custom projection functions. You must provide two functions in this shader. Both functions must be provided and return correct results for your rendering to work in all cases. As a starting point, here are the definitions for these functions that are used when custom ones are not provided.		
  









			
The other convenience variations of these functions such as vec3 TDCamToProj(vec3 p) will automatically call the correct one of either of the two above functions. You can use uniforms/samplers in this shader code by declaring them here and providing them in the GLSL page of the Render TOP.

parameters.name: Background Color
parameters.label: Background Color
parameters.description:
bgcolor -  - Set the background color of the view when using the light as a camera.

 bgcolorr - bgcolorg - bgcolorb - bgcolora -

parameters.name: Red
parameters.label: Red
parameters.description: bgcolorr - bgcolorg - bgcolorb - bgcolora -

parameters.name: Material
parameters.label: Material
parameters.description: material - Selects a MAT to apply to the geometry inside.

parameters.name: Render
parameters.label: Render
parameters.description: render - Whether the 's geometry is visible in the Render TOP. This parameter works in conjunction (logical AND) with the 's Render Flag.

parameters.name: Draw Priority
parameters.label: Draw Priority
parameters.description: drawpriority - Determines the order in which the Components are drawn. Smaller values get drawn after larger values. The value is compared with other Components in the same parent , or if the  is the top level one listed in the Render 's '' parameter, then against other top-level Components listed there. This value is most often used to help with Transparency.

parameters.name: Pick Priority
parameters.label: Pick Priority
parameters.description: pickpriority - When using a Render Pick CHOP or a Render Pick DAT, there is an option to have a 'Search Area'. If multiple objects are found within the search area, the pick priority can be used to select one object over another. A higher value will get picked over a lower value. This does not affect draw order, or objects that are drawn over each other on the same pixel. Only one will be visible for a pick per pixel.

parameters.name: Wireframe Color
parameters.label: Wireframe Color
parameters.description:
wcolor -  - Use the R, G, and B fields to set the 's color when displayed in wireframe shading mode.

 wcolorr - wcolorg - wcolorb -

parameters.name: Red
parameters.label: Red
parameters.description: wcolorr - wcolorg - wcolorb -

parameters.name: Light Mask
parameters.label: Light Mask
parameters.description: lightmask - By default all lights used in the Render TOP will affect geometry renderer. This parameter can be used to specify a sub-set of lights to be used for this particular geometry. The lights must be listed in the Render TOP as well as this parameter to be used.

parameters.name: Extension
parameters.label: Extension
parameters.description:
ext - Sequence of info for creating extensions on this component



  ext0object - A number of class instances that can be attached to the component.


    
  ext0name - Optional name to search by, instead of the instance class name.



  ext0promote - Controls whether or not the extensions are visible directly at the component level, or must be accessed through the .ext member.  Example:  n.Somefunction vs n.ext.Somefunction

parameters.name: Object
parameters.label: Object
parameters.description: ext0object - A number of class instances that can be attached to the component.

parameters.name: Name
parameters.label: Name
parameters.description: ext0name - Optional name to search by, instead of the instance class name.

parameters.name: Promote
parameters.label: Promote
parameters.description: ext0promote - Controls whether or not the extensions are visible directly at the component level, or must be accessed through the .ext member.  Example:  n.Somefunction vs n.ext.Somefunction

parameters.name: Re-Init Extensions
parameters.label: Re-Init Extensions
parameters.description: reinitextensions - Recompile all extension objects. Normally extension objects are compiled only when they are referenced and their definitions have changed.

parameters.name: Parent Shortcut
parameters.label: Parent Shortcut
parameters.description: parentshortcut - Specifies a name you can use anywhere inside the component as the path to that component. See Parent Shortcut.

parameters.name: Global OP Shortcut
parameters.label: Global OP Shortcut
parameters.description: opshortcut - Specifies a name you can use anywhere at all as the path to that component. See Global OP Shortcut.

parameters.name: Internal OP
parameters.label: Internal OP
parameters.description:
iop - Sequence header for internal operators.



  iop0shortcut - Specifies a name you can use anywhere inside the component as a path to "Internal " below. See Internal Operators.



  iop0op - The path to the Internal OP inside this component. See Internal Operators.

parameters.name: Shortcut
parameters.label: Shortcut
parameters.description: iop0shortcut - Specifies a name you can use anywhere inside the component as a path to "Internal " below. See Internal Operators.

parameters.name: OP
parameters.label: OP
parameters.description: iop0op - The path to the Internal OP inside this component. See Internal Operators.

parameters.name: Node View
parameters.label: Node View
parameters.description:
nodeview -  - Determines what is displayed in the node viewer, also known as the Node Viewer. Some options will not be available depending on the  type (Object Component, Panel Component, Misc.)

 default - Displays the default viewer for the component type, a 3D Viewer for Object COMPS and a  Viewer for Panel COMPs. opviewer - Displays the node viewer from any operator specified in the Operator Viewer parameter below.

parameters.name: Default Viewer
parameters.label: Default Viewer
parameters.description: default - Displays the default viewer for the component type, a 3D Viewer for Object COMPS and a  Viewer for Panel COMPs. opviewer - Displays the node viewer from any operator specified in the Operator Viewer parameter below.

parameters.name: Operator Viewer
parameters.label: Operator Viewer
parameters.description: opviewer - Select which operator's node viewer to use when the Node View parameter above is set to Operator .

parameters.name: Enable Cloning
parameters.label: Enable Cloning
parameters.description: enablecloning - Control if the OP should be actively cloneing. Turning this off causes this node to stop cloning it's ' Master'.

parameters.name: Enable Cloning Pulse
parameters.label: Enable Cloning Pulse
parameters.description: enablecloningpulse - Instantaneously clone the contents.

parameters.name: Clone Master
parameters.label: Clone Master
parameters.description: clone -  to a component used as the Master Clone.

parameters.name: Load on Demand
parameters.label: Load on Demand
parameters.description: loadondemand - Loads the component into memory only when required. Good to use for components that are not always used in the project.

parameters.name: Enable External .tox
parameters.label: Enable External .tox
parameters.description: enableexternaltox - When on (default), the external  file will be loaded when the  starts and the contents of the  will match that of the external . This can be turned off to avoid loading from the referenced external  on startup if desired (the contents of the  are instead loaded from the  file). Useful if you wish to have a  reference an external  but not always load from it unless you specifically push the Re-Init Network parameter button.

parameters.name: Enable External .tox Pulse
parameters.label: Enable External .tox Pulse
parameters.description: enableexternaltoxpulse - This button will re-load from the external  file (if present).

parameters.name: External .tox Path
parameters.label: External .tox Path
parameters.description: externaltox -  to a  file on disk which will source the component's contents upon start of a . This allows for components to contain networks that can be updated independently. If the  file can not be found, whatever the  file was saved with will be loaded.

parameters.name: Reload Custom Parameters
parameters.label: Reload Custom Parameters
parameters.description: reloadcustom - When this checkbox is enabled, the values of the component's Custom Parameters are reloaded when the .tox is reloaded. This only affects top-level parameters on the component, all parameters on nodes inside the component are always reloaded with the .tox.

parameters.name: Reload Built-In Parameters
parameters.label: Reload Built-In Parameters
parameters.description: reloadbuiltin - When this checkbox is enabled, the values of the component's built-in parameters are reloaded when the .tox is reloaded. This only affects top-level parameters on the component, all parameters on nodes inside the component are always reloaded with the .tox.

parameters.name: Save Backup of External
parameters.label: Save Backup of External
parameters.description: savebackup - When this checkbox is enabled, a backup copy of the component specified by the External  parameter is saved in the  file.  This backup copy will be used if the External  can not be found. This may happen if the  was renamed, deleted, or the  file is running on another computer that is missing component media.

parameters.name: Sub-Component to Load
parameters.label: Sub-Component to Load
parameters.description: subcompname - When loading from an External  file, this option allows you to reach into the  and pull out a  and make that the top-level , ignoring everything else in the file (except for the contents of that ). For example if a  file named project1 contains project1/geo1, putting geo1 as the Sub- to Load, will result in geo1 being loaded in place of the current . If this parameter is blank, it just loads the  file normally using the top level  in the file.

parameters.name: Relative File Path Behavior
parameters.label: Relative File Path Behavior
parameters.description:
relpath -  - Set whether the child file paths within this  are relative to the  itself or the , or inherit from parent.

 inherit - Inherit setting from parent. project - The path, when specified as a relative path, will be relative to the  file. externaltox - The path, when specified as a relative path, will be relative to the  file. When no external  file is specified, or when Enable External  is not toggled on, this doesn't have any impact.

parameters.name: Use Parent's Behavior
parameters.label: Use Parent's Behavior
parameters.description: inherit - Inherit setting from parent. project - The path, when specified as a relative path, will be relative to the  file. externaltox - The path, when specified as a relative path, will be relative to the  file. When no external  file is specified, or when Enable External  is not toggled on, this doesn't have any impact.
